title: What is the "magical problem of the endangered soul" and how does it relate to modern man's spiritual struggles?
first_phrase: In this text, the author critiques the idea that studying psychopathology and psychoanalysis can offer insight into traditional magical practices. The concept of the "magical problem of the endangered soul" is discussed in relation to schizophrenia and hysteria. However, the author argues that this perspective is limited in its understanding of ancient magical traditions, and that modern societies still engage in magical thinking. Despite the author's criticisms, they acknowledge that there is some value in studying psychopathology to understand human experience. The author mentions the work of De Martino, who was able to recognize some truths despite the flawed nature of his material.

last_phrase: In conclusion, despite the subjective and hallucinatory nature of psychopathology and psychoanalysis, there exists a unique form of modern magic that grants reality to an otherwise desolate and mechanistic world. While this barrier protects against risks to the soul, it also renders the spiritual substance within inconsistent and shapeless. Those who seek to establish psychic connections must be aware of the potential dangers involved, even more so in today's environment.
